repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Refinery Energy Conservation and
            Modernization Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Refinery Energy
            Conservation and Modernization Project for Pakistan was
            satisfactory. The project achieved its major objectives, its
            impact on institutional development has been substantial,
            sustainability is likely, and both the Bank and Borrower
            performed satisfactorily. Several lessons can be learned
            from this project. First, there is a need for a much higher
            degree of autonomy to parastatals and trust in key
            officials. Overall, the state-owned refineries can perform
            better if given autonomy and the MOP and MPNR's
            monitoring role is confined to ensuring that the refineries
            stay within the policy guidelines defined by the Government.
            Second, in light of the substantial investments required to
            reconfigure the NRL in the medium term, the GOP should
            seriously consider developing a strategy for the involvement
            of the private sector by appropriating changes in the
            ownership structure of the NRL. Finally, the Bank should pay
            more attention to the evaluation of the implementing
            agency's authority and capability when designing and
            appraising a project.

repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Refinery Energy Conservation and
            Modernization Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Refinery Energy Conservation and
            Modernization Project aims to reduce refinery energy
            consumption; increase crude processing capacity; modify
            National Refinery Ltd.'s (NRL) refinery output mix to
            better match demand; and to strengthen production
            optimization and control systems and train staff.  Further,
            the project aims to promote a refinery pricing system that
            will provide adequate incentives for efficiency
            improvements, and assist Government in formulating an
            optimal investment program for the refinery sector as a
            whole.  With this in mind, the project includes (i)
            balancing and modernization of the crude processing unit;
            (ii) a captive power plant; (iii) debottlenecking of the
            hydo-treater and platformer; and (iv) process modifications
            to lube unit I.  In addition, the project supports (v)
            efficiency improvement measures; and (vi) studies, training,
            technical assistance, research and development.  These
            measures, identified under the previous refinery engineering
            project, will yield significant benefits at relatively low
            incremental cost, by modifying existing process units and
            adding ancilliary facilities.
